title: 105_s248
content: The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals is established to study the current division of the United States into judicial circuits, analyze the structure of the Federal Court of Appeals system, and make recommendations for changes in circuit boundaries or structure to improve the efficiency of the courts. The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals will consist of 12 members appointed by various officials within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointments, and the Commission will elect a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. The Commission on Structural Alternatives for the Federal Courts of Appeals will elect a Chair and Vice Chair from its members. Seven members constitute a quorum, with 3 able to conduct hearings. Members of the Commission, whether officers or full-time employees of the United States, will not receive additional compensation but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses. Private members will receive $200 per diem for each day of engagement in Commission duties. The Commission may appoint an Executive Director who will receive compensation not exceeding the rate for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Executive Director can appoint additional personnel as needed without following certain regulations, and their compensation should not exceed the annual maximum rate for a position above GS-15. The Executive Director can hire experts and consultants at rates not exceeding the highest General Schedule pay rates. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts will provide administrative and financial services for the Commission, while the Federal Judicial Center will offer research services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission is authorized to request information from government entities to carry out its functions. A report must be submitted to the President and Congress within 2 years of the seventh member's appointment. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report. The Senate Judiciary Committee must act on the report within 60 days. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations up to $1,300,000 is granted to the Commission to fulfill the Act's purposes, with funds remaining available until expended.
